author: langers
content:
<@!784446040073175040> and I would like to thank everyone for their time on the eth2 call.

The PR (https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/pull/2454) has seen some healthy debate around the proposed 0x02 withdrawal credential solution. Please continue to contribute to the discussion - having multiple perspectives can only strengthen the ultimate solution.

To reiterate the problem we have encountered: decentralised staking pools (such as Rocket Pool) that promote independent node operators are unfairly disadvantaged compared to centralised pools (which control their own nodes).
As isidorosp said in the PR comments:
"the concern around network/ecosystem health from any possible increased incentives for side-channeling payments for block production should be weighed against the concern of a non-decentralized staking landscape, and the latter is more important, especially when considering the ethos of Ethereum in general."

For evidence on why this latter point is compelling: 
https://twitter.com/sparkpool_eth/status/1395662646951641090

We feel this is an important issue to be addressed for a variety of reasons, but we are supportive of the eth2 implementors' efforts to minimise scope creep to ensure delivery. *If* the solution was refined and agreed we would not require it to be part of the merge. Similar to 0x01 we would be fine with a promise. We would assume that when withdrawals are implemented (approx next hard fork after merge) it would be an opportune time for 0x02 to be implemented.

Many thanks again and we look forward to discussing the proposal further.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think that ensuring that solo staking has the most "advantages" over both decentralized and centralized pools is the most important endpoint to target.  In fact, I am of the opinion (not shared by all) that if we can do things to actively make pooling unattractive we *should* because pooling in general is bad for the long-term health of the platform.

author: sky.cactus
content: While I agree that decentralized staking pools are better than centralized staking pools, any change that makes *any* pool better than or equal to solo validators is a bit of a non-starter.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content:
solo staking > decentralized pool staking > centralized pool staking
This change would remove one of the advantages of solo staking over decentralized staking, which would both make decentralized pool staking even better than centralized pool staking, but it would *also* reduce the benefit of solo staking over decentralized staking.

content: The reason I think solo pools are healthier for the network than decentralized pools like this (and all other designs I have seen proposed) is that it gives leverage to an attacker.  Essentially, an attacker now needs half as much money to attack the network because they can double their "voting power" by being a rocket pool node operator.

content: We are already seeing out of band networks start to be used more and more across the ecosystem because there are small advantages to using them.  Things could get worse if it is also *cheaper* to use them, which is what I believe will be the case here.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm not convinced that in-band payments will reign supreme simply by nature of being the default.  I am concerned that we may end up in a future where no one is using the built-in gossip mechanisms for transaction propagation because it is cheaper to use the out of band systems.  Unfortunately, this can come with its own set of problems if the out of band system has ecosystem health downsides (related to end-user security and censorship resistance).

author: jgm
content:
I'm not sure I would agree that out of band would be cheaper.  The additional work and cost required to provide a separate payment to a non-coinbase address would make it more likely a rare occurrence than the common case, and would run the risk of the block producer being caught taking out of band payments (at which point the decentralized pool could have some punishment method).

As for no-one using in-band protocols for transaction propagation: if there were no in-band transactions then it would wipe out a large chunk of ability for MEV, as there would be no mempool to mine.  And so value for the out-of-band transactions would drop, more transactions would move in-band, and the pendulum swings.

It's definitely a dynamic system, and I don't think that out of band transactions will go away, but I also don't think that in band transactions will go away and so I continue to see benefits for the `0x02` credentials.  It may not be the best solution, but it's a solution that has benefits and is consistent with previous statements from the eth2 team about their desire for who controls funds in a validator.

author: sky.cactus
content: Shadow mempools just reduce the number of people who can extract MEV, they don't remove the MEV.

On thing I think that wasnâ€™t discussed nearly enough though was the ability to use tokenised staked ETH more or less the same as regular ETH when we have merged:

author: chrisco512
content: Ultimately under a dpool, it's a collection of individuals that are running the validators. To your point earlier, DAO staking indeed does help Ethereum from an economic security standpoint. without decentralized pools, DEXes and other DAOs are forced to pay Coinbase and Binance for security while CEXes use MEV to extract value from DEX customers and 1559 burns the gas that DEX customers spend.
